 I would like to try to refocus my argument about Matthew 21:5, and why it is such a fatal mistake IMO, by examining more closely the prophesy it is tied to, that of Zechariah 9:9. It is my hope that you may understand more fully why this "smoking gun" is not some simple translational error, but one that calls into question fundamental assertions of your faith. 
 
 It has been alleged by Christians that the Old Testament contains predictions about a coming Jewish Messiah, or "anointed king" and that Jesus fulfilled all of them. Predictions about his virgin birth, his ministry, his betrayal and crucifixion--in other words, the main outlines of his life --were covered by the major prophets, most notably, Isaiah, Jeremiah and Ezekiel. There is another grouping in the Bible, the minor prophets, who predicted more localized, inconsequential events and as a result are marginalized in importance. Zechariah belongs to this latter group, as you are probably aware. He wrote about events related specifically to Syria.
 
 Scholars have pointed out the disjointed writing style in Zechariah, noting how two different writers are probably at work, notably from chapter 9 onwards, but nevertheless have brought to light the person the author(s) was referring to in 9:9. They believe it was a Judean governor named Zerubbabel, a man of Davidic bloodlines, who rebuilt the Jewish temple. 
 http://www.infidels.org/library/modern/robert_price/psychics.html

 Did Jesus and his disciples, being mistaken about the allusion in Zechariah, stage a similar event to make it appear prophecy was being fulfilled?
 
 Or did the author of Matthew, in attempting to make all apparent prophesies of the Messiah come true, mistakenly assume the same mistake of Mark, which was a misunderstanding of Zechariah, and continue to expand the fabrication?
 
 Those are the only two possibilities I can think of. What do you see?
